dialogues.text: She had invited Frank into her home. He was good to her son. He was good to her. She omitted the fact that they were in love.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Adele, these situations are never simple. Never clean. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May take years for you to fully weave it all together. Perhaps before you put this kind of statement into record, you might want to take a little time to think about what actually happened. Harboring a fugitive is a major crime that we don’t look lightly upon. And of course there’s delinquency to a minor. You could lose custody of your son... Adele looks to Henry and back to the prosecutor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old steel bars have rusted over. Frank is let out of his cell. He walks up to a pass through window, where he is handed a lunch tray.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They gave Frank ten years for the escape and fifteen for the kidnapping. Corridor of lunch tables. Frank sits down and eats.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was designated high-risk and required a maximum security prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele's station wagon pulls up to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele is being explained something by a PRISON GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mother tried to visit him once, but was told he was doing solitary. Sometime after that, they transferred him to someplace in Massachusetts. INT. KITCHEN, ADELE’S HOUSE - DAY 250 Adele tries to open a can of soup. Her hands shake worse we've ever seen them.  251 252 253 254 255 118.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The shaking got worse. Adele gives up on the can.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Within a month, my mother voluntarily relinquished custody of me to my father. EXT. GERALD’S HOUSE - DAY 251 Gerald helps Henry with his stuff, carrying it from the minivan up to the house. INT. RICHARD’S ROOM - DAY 252 Gerald finishes installing a bunk bed. Richard isn’t thri INT. RICHARD’S ROOM - NIGHT 253 Henry lies on the top bunk, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The nights were quiet now. Save for when Chloe woke up with a nightmare. We hear Chloe crying. We hear Marjorie get out of bed. INT. BREAKFAST ROOM, GERALD’S HOUSE - DAY 254 Henry and Richard eat cereal across from each other. Marj makes sure Chloe eats. Gerald stops reading his paper to something to Henry, but comes up empty.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My Father rarely knew what to say. More often than not, he just kept quiet. The newspapers had said it all anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry transfers books from his backpack to his locker.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Seventh grade came with a new and unexpected fame that translated into something like popularity.  119. We begin to catch everyone around Henry taking notice of Rachel McCann stops next to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Is it true that he tortured you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I heard your mother was his sex slave. Henry doesn’t know how to process this statement.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That’s weird.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I just wanted you to know I think you're incredibly brave. If you ever want to talk about it, I’m here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Rachel are walking amongst the trees.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two months later, I got my first kiss all over again. Henry and Rachel have the sweetest kiss. 257 INT. LIVING ROOM, ADELE’S HOUSE - DAY 257 Henry steps inside. Adele is making busy. Putting things away. Acting as though she is overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I visited my mother, she would act busy and distracted. Calls to make. Chores to do. I think my presence made her uncomfortable. A strange reminder of what was missing. 258 INT. ADELE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 258 Adele’s night stand is a mountain of books.  259 260

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The only distraction she had was her reading. We find Adele in bed reading a book.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY
dialogues.text: In particular, a book called Living The Good Life, about a couple who dropped out of society and moved to rural Maine to live off of the land. INT. KITCHEN, ADELE’S HOUSE - DAY 259 Adele and Henry are eating soup. The book is sitting open face down, half-read for the fiftieth time.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: All those two had was each other. That was enough. EXT. GERALD’S HOUSE - DAY 260 Henry, now 16 YEARS OLD, comes whistling out of the drive on a mountain bike, wearing a flannel and cargo pants.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By my junior year, people hardly brought up the events leading up to seventh grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry hangs with friends. He flirts with Rachel, now 16.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: First the first time, I had someone to call a girlfriend. INT. ADELE’S STATION WAGON - NIGHT 260B Henry and Rachel are driving down the highway on a date. There’s a BUMP, and the car begins to drive lop sided. They’ve run a FLAT TIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is up on a JACK. RACHEL watches as Henry rolls ov the spare tire and begins to fix the flat.  120A.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Impressive. Henry controls a proud smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, wearing a baseball uniform, takes a practice swing the way to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you can believe it, I even made the varsity roster. Henry lines up at the plate. We hear just under his breat

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: See the ball.. Pitch. Swing. Crack! Line drive between left and center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Fall. The foliage is incredible.  263 121.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As my senior year began, my father realized if we didn’t take some time for the two of us to bond, it would never actually happen. Over the crest of a hill, Henry and Gerald appear on bicy wearing road bike cycling gear. We follow them along the rolling hills.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We carved a route along the Connecticut River just as the trees were changing. We stayed at motels and found dives to dine in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Gerald eat at a dark wooden table with red ging table cloths and little yellow candles.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: There’s something I’ve been meaning to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh, dad, please don’t. We’re having such a pleasant time. Gerald laughs it off a little.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: Look, this is all I’1ll say. Everybody talks about all this crazy, wild passion. That’s how it goes in the songs. Your mother was like that. Henry looks up.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was in love with love. She couldn’t do anything partway. Henry has stopped eating. He never gets to hear these thi

dialogues.speaker: GERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That trip we took to California. We had no money. Slept in the car. One town in Nebraska, we got a motel room with a kitchenette. We made spaghetti on a hot plate. She was a terrific woman. Funny. Beautiful.  264 265 122. Gerald smiles. Lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had never thought I looked anything like my father. We seemed so different. But looking across the table then, as he spoke about my mother, I recognized, weirdly, something familiar. I could imagine him being young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele and Gerald are making spaghetti on that hot plate.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just as my mom described. They dance.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Knowing just how much pressure to apply to a woman’s back. He dips her.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY
dialogues.text: The crazy young man she had trusted to keep her from falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerald continues.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: A better man might have stayed around to help her through all that sadness. I couldn’t bear it. I wanted a regular life. With Marjorie, it wasn’t as if I could erase what happened, but it was easier for me, not to think about it. Where for your mother, the story never went away. Henry and his father make real long lasting eye contact. refusing to get closer. Both refusing to cry.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what these last few years have done to repair... but I’m sorry I cut out on you.  266 267 268 269 123. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Gerald needs to stand up before he loses it.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: I’m going to get the check.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The next morning we rode a little more, but the trip had outrun its natural course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive in silence down the beautiful Autumn highway.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On the way home, I mostly slept. INT. HALLWAY, GERALD’S HOUSE - DAY 267 Henry approaches his father to say something.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The next day, when I suggested I move back in with my mother for the rest of senior year, he didn’t argue. They hug. EXT. ADELE’S HOUSE - DAY 268 Henry walks his suitcase back up his mom’s front steps. H gives her a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That winter I convinced my mom to get what Marjorie would call a real job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele leads a dance class.  270 271 272 273 274 124.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The senior center heard about her former dance career and reached out to see if she would lead some of the old-timers through Fox Trots, Waltzes, and the Two Step. She takes one of the older men in her hands and starts dancing him around the room.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 271
dialogues.text: INT. KITCHEN, ADELE’S HOUSE - DAY 272 Henry prepares dinner for his mother.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was there in my mom's tiny kitchen, my final summer at home, that I first tried my hand at cooking. Henry pulls something out of the oven and sets it down in front of Adele. She can’t quite believe it. It’s the pie. Frank's pie. The smell alone makes her emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adult Henry sits frozen, staring at the letter in his han  275 276 277 278 125.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unmistakable back of Frank’s head. Hair now peppered grey. We don’t see his face. He’s at a desk. Writing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Henry. I hope you will remember me. We once spent Labor Day weekend together. Five of the best days of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry reads along.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had always wondered who you would become and what you would look like. And then, one day while flipping through a magazine, I came across a familiar looking pie and there you were. Henry’s eyes begin to moisten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now see Frank. Just as handsome. Somehow prison has no destroyed all that is good in the depth of his eyes. The library is so modern, it almost looks like a high school.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The opportunities for me to impart knowledge of any kind have been limited in my life, so it’s nice to think I might have contributed some small piece of wisdom or know-how. I’m proud of you. INT. HENRY’S MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT 278 Henry is in bed with his WIFE, a brunette of similar age has a similar literary quality to her. They read the lett

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will understand if you choose not to respond to this letter. Your silence would be as much word as I would need, to discontinue any thought of further communication.  279 280 281 126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks out a thin window on a rainy day. The changes the prison are enormous. His bed is stainless steel. The window, a long horizontal slit in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: However, I am due to be released shortly. I’m no longer young, but I have plenty of good health remaining, and I'd like to live much the way we discussed that weekend, back when we thought we'd be a family. Frank hears a knock on his cell door. He passes the seale envelope to the mail service. INT. HENRY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 280 Henry and his wife continue to read the letter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Most likely, your mother has remarried by now and is living with a husband somewhere. While this thought haunts me, I’d be relieved to know that she had found happiness. She deserves it. Henry looks to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But on the off chance that she might be alone, I wanted to ask you whether I might write her a letter. I promise you, I would sooner cut off my own hand than bring any more grief to Adele. Henry puts down the letter.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wrote him back that day to say it wouldn't be difficult to locate my mother. She lived at the same address. EXT. ADELE’S HOUSE - MODERN DAY 281 As we push in, we notice that the house has deteriorated.  282 283 284 285 127.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And it would be far less difficult to locate his place in her heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parking lot and a fence.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sex is a drug, Eleanor had told me. We see Adele now in her late fifties. She leans against h car wearing a coat, waiting for the fence to open.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The real drug, I came to believe, was love. The fence begins to move. It reveals Frank. Adele sits up They see each other for the first time in nearly twenty years. It’s as emotional as you’d imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Frank and Adele driving along a country road. Everything is quiet and serene.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rare love, for which no explanation might be found. They look at each other, checking to make sure they’re actually sitting in the same car. She holds his arm.

dialogues.speaker: ADULT HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They were two people who could not go out into the world, so they made a world with each other.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 284
dialogues.text: EXT. FRANK’S FARM - LATE AFTERNOON 285 Henry and his wife find the old dirt driveway that leads to Frank’s grandmother’s farm. They turn and start up the bumpy road. + eH  286 287 288 128. INT. HENRY’S CAR - SAME 286 Henry takes in the scene. This is obviously his first tim visiting the farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry steps out of the car. His wife opens the rear passe door and picks up their INFANT out of the carseat. Henry looks up at the farm house. His mother and Frank nowhere to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and his wife come around the back side of the farm house. Looking down past the field where we once saw Fran and Mandy run as teenagers, we see a small garden. In the late afternoon light, we can see Frank and Adele picking vegetables. Perhaps even a few roaming chickens. After a beat, they look back up and wave. Henry smiles as he leads his family down to the garden. Perhaps rolling up his sleeves. Adele notices her son approaching and stops.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) You brought the baby. FADE TO BLACK.
